question.text: When $\mathrm{CO}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}$ is passed over red hot coke it partially gets reduced to $\mathrm{CO}(g)$. Upon passing $0.5 \mathrm{~L}$ of $\mathrm{CO}_2(g)$ over red hot coke, the total volume of the gases increased to $700 \mathrm{~mL}$. The composition of the gaseous mixture at STP is

solution.text:
$\mathrm{CO}_2+\mathrm{C} \longrightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}$
Stoichoimetry ratio is $1: 2$
AT STP, $P=1 \mathrm{~atm}, T=273 \mathrm{~K}, R=0.0821$
Initial moles of $\mathrm{CO}_2 ; n\left(\mathrm{CO}_2\right.$ initial $)=\frac{P V}{R T}$ $=\frac{1 \times 0.5}{0.0821 \times 273}=0.022 \mathrm{~mole}$
In final mixture no. of moles; $n\left(\mathrm{CO}_2 / \mathrm{CO}\right.$ mixture)
$$
=\frac{1 \times 0.7}{0.0821 \times 273}=0.031
$$
Increase in volume is by $=0.031-0.022$ $=0.009$ mole of gas
Final no. of moles of $\mathrm{CO}$ i.e. $n_{\text {(CO final) }}$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{\text {(CO final) }}=2 n_{\left(\mathrm{CO}_2 \text { initial }\right)}-n_{\left(\mathrm{CO}_2\right. \text { final) }} \\
& \quad=2\left(0.022-\mathrm{n}_{\left(\mathrm{CO}_2 \text { final }\right)}\right. \\
& \left.n_{\text {(CO final) }}=0.044-2 n_{\text {(CO }} \text { final }\right) \\
& \therefore \text { Now, } n_{\text {(CO final) }}+n_{\text {(CO final) }}=0.031 \\
& n_{\left(\mathrm{CO}_2\right. \text { final) }}=0.031-n_{\text {(CO final) })} \ldots \text { (iii) }
\end{aligned}
$$
Substituting (ii) in eq. (i)
$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{\text {(CO final) }}=0.044-2\left[0.031-n_{\text {(CO final) }}\right. \\
& n_{\text {(CO final) }}=0.044-0.062+2 n_{\text {(CO final })}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
n_{(\mathrm{CO} \text { final) }}=0.018 \mathrm{~mol} .
$$
Volume of $\mathrm{CO}=V=\frac{n R T}{P}=\frac{0.018 \times 0.0821 \times 273}{1}$ $=0.40$ Litre
and volume of $\mathrm{CO}_2=0.7$ litre $-0.4$ litre $=0.3$ litre
$$
\therefore \mathrm{CO}_2=300 \mathrm{~mL}, \mathrm{CO}=400 \mathrm{~mL}
$$
